Specific Details: We highlighted the need for political support for a locally led agri environment scheme for the Wicklow Uplands. It has been advised that there will a competitive call for applications for the scheme in 2016. Given our work in the area in the past five years in looking for a locally led agri-environment scheme, we are well positioned as a forerunner to develop and implement one of the first 'uplands' schemes in the country.
DPOs Lobbied: Simon Harris|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Andrew Doyle|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Billy Timmins|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Stephen Donnelly|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Anne Ferris|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: We highlighted the need for political support for a locally led agri environment scheme for the Wicklow Uplands. It has been advised that there will a competitive call for applications for the scheme in 2016. Given our work in the area in the past five years in looking for a locally led agri-environment scheme, we are well positioned as a forerunner to develop and implement one of the first 'uplands' schemes in the country.
Intended Results: We had concerns that the scheme may be awarded to another less prepared group due to strong political support. This would not only be unjustified but could also result in a weaker scheme, due to lack of preparations. Therefore we asked that the Wicklow TDs would back our application when the time comes.
Lobbying Activities: There was a joint meeting of the Wicklow TDs arranged in Leinster House, November 2015, where we highlighted our work to date in preparation for the scheme. We also highlighted our concerns that political backing could result in the award of the scheme to another group over preparatory work.|Meeting|1::An individual meeting was held with TDs absent from the joint meeting. Again outlining the need for political backing|Meeting|1

Specific Details: We looked for support on the review of section 40 of the wildlife act. This was in particular relation to the burning of vegetation in upland areas to allow for better vegetation management
DPOs Lobbied: Simon Harris|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Andrew Doyle|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Billy Timmins|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Anne Ferris|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Stephen Donnelly|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: We looked for support on the review of section 40 of the wildlife act. This was in particular relation to the burning of vegetation in upland areas to allow for better vegetation management
Intended Results: The burning season was reduced by 6 weeks in 2000 without any consultation with landowners. We sought to have the burning season extended to allow for a more managed approach to vegetation management.
Lobbying Activities: A joint meeting of the 5 Wicklow TDs was held in Leinster House November 2015. We outlined that the burning dates for upland vegetation should be inline with the UK and Northern Ireland burning season.|Meeting|1::A follow up meeting was had with TDs absent from the joint meeting above where it was again outlined that the burning dates for upland vegetation should be inline with the UK and Northern Ireland burning season.|Meeting|1

Specific Details: Submission on the taskforce on introduction of personal budgets
DPOs Lobbied: Simon Harris|Minister|Department of Health::Finian McGrath|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Submission on the taskforce on introduction of personal budgets
Intended Results: To suggest recommendations to the Government on the establishment of a taskforce to explore the introduction of personal budgets for persons with disabilities. Inclusion Ireland believes that the taskforce must deliver the necessary changes outlined in the Programme for Partnership Government and ensure that people with disabilities have more choice, control and independence over the services that they receive.
Lobbying Activities: We provided the Ministers with a submission that was based on a consultation with and feedback from those who attended the personal budgets seminar in Dublin on May 30th, 2016. It draws on the evidence presented and from the views expressed by those present on the day, many of whom were speaking from personal, lived experience. A number of organisations and individuals opted to be signatories to this document and some of these also provided comment on its content.|Email|1

Lobbying Activities:
Dear Minister,
May I first of all congratulate you on your appointment to your new post. 
I would like to join the queue of people seeking a meeting with you. 
We obviously would like to appraise you on the current work of the Irish Kidney Association and our goals for the future of our patients. 
There is one urgent matter which could already be on your desk, in relation to living donor expenses and patients expenses from the treatment abroad fund. This has been awaiting a signature from a Minister for some time and is affecting patients treatments in the UK. 
Our agenda for a meeting would include. The current state of Kidney Transplantation in Ireland, Organ Donor Awareness Campaigns – funding, Transport of Patients to and from centres - Acute Hospital Groups – equity of treatment, National Renal Office (NRO), Medical Cards – Renal Patients Chronic Long-term for life and Home Treatments – out of pocket expenses.
Hopefully, you can see us sooner rather than later but we look forward|Letter|1

Specific Details: On behalf of the 470,000 people with asthma, we lobbied to have the following matters addressed in Budget 2017: (1) Reduce the cost of living with asthma by subsidising asthma medication. (2) To improve Secondary Care services for people with asthma (3) Improve Primary Care services for people with asthma. (4) Improve outdoor and indoor air quality. (5) Reduce the threat from tobacco products.
DPOs Lobbied: Simon Harris|Minister|Department of Health::Denis Naughten|Minister|Department of Environment, Climate and Communications::John Dolan|Senator|Seanad
Subject Matter: On behalf of the 470,000 people with asthma, we lobbied to have the following matters addressed in Budget 2017: (1) Reduce the cost of living with asthma by subsidising asthma medication. (2) To improve Secondary Care services for people with asthma (3) Improve Primary Care services for people with asthma. (4) Improve outdoor and indoor air quality. (5) Reduce the threat from tobacco products.
Intended Results: For these matters to be addressed in Budget 2017 through policy and Funding Announcements as part of the budgetary process.
Lobbying Activities:
All 3 meetings took place in Leinster House. The agenda was as follows:

>Reduce the cost of living with asthma by subsidising asthma medication through the long term illness scheme or the introduction of a chronic disease card

>To improve Secondary Care services for people with asthma by recruiting additional asthma specilaists particularly in the area of Paediatric medicine

>Improve Primary Care services for people with asthma by delivering on the commitment to provide everyone with asthma with a free structured annual review with their GP as per the National Clinical Programme for Asthma.

Specific Details: Concern re governance changes in HSE affecting the Mental Health Division and dilution of focused leadership in the Mental Health/Psychiatry area at the highest level in the HSE. The College and other bodies involved in supporting people with mental health problems, believe that this is another sign of decreased commitment by the HSE to this vulnerable group of patients and their carers and contrary to A Vision for Change policy.
DPOs Lobbied: Simon Harris|Minister|Department of Health
Subject Matter: Concern re governance changes in HSE affecting the Mental Health Division and dilution of focused leadership in the Mental Health/Psychiatry area at the highest level in the HSE. The College and other bodies involved in supporting people with mental health problems, believe that this is another sign of decreased commitment by the HSE to this vulnerable group of patients and their carers and contrary to A Vision for Change policy.
Intended Results: Urgent attention given by Minister Harris to the now lack of a National Director for Mental Health which is a further diversion from the structures set out in Government Policy. Though the post of National Director for Mental Health probably fell short of what is recommended in A Vision for Change, the current developments will leave us a long way from having the focused leadership in the health services that the needs of those with mental illness requires and deserves.

Specific Details: To discuss the role of Nutritional Therapy within the health sector and introduce NTOI, the Association representing nutritional therapists in Ireland
DPOs Lobbied: Simon Harris|Minister|Department of Health
Subject Matter: To discuss the role of Nutritional Therapy within the health sector and introduce NTOI, the Association representing nutritional therapists in Ireland
Intended Results: Explore the possibilities of having Nutritional Therapy recognised and regulated as a complementary health therapy
Lobbying Activities:
2 NTOI (Nutritional Therapists of Ireland) members, Maev Creaven and Edelle O'Doherty met with Kieran Duffy and Aidan Tumbleton on Friday 23 February at 10am in Hawkins House to discuss the current role of NTOI as the representative body for qualified Nutritional Therapists in Ireland since 2007.
The role  Nutritional Therapists play in the health of Irish society today, in particular the prevention and management of many current chronic health conditions in Ireland, such as obesity, metabolic syndrome and Type 2 diabetes.
The development of a relationship between the department of health and NTOI to reflect this role.|Meeting|1
Grassroots directive: Discuss the current role of NTOI as the representative body for qualified Nutritional Therapists in Ireland since 2007 The role  Nutritional Therapists play in the health of Irish society today, in particular the prevention and management of many current chronic health conditions in Ireland, such as obesity, metabolic syndrome and Type 2 diabetes, to name but a few. The development of a relationship between the department of health and NTOI to reflect this role.

Specific Details: A coalition of children's palliative care service providers and consultants in pediatric palliative care met with Minister for Health Simon Harris. The purpose of the meeting was to highlight their concerns over the slow progress of a number of key recommendations in the 'Evaluation of the Children's Palliative Care Programme' report launched by the Minister in November 2016.
DPOs Lobbied: Simon Harris|Minister|Department of Health
Subject Matter: A coalition of children's palliative care service providers and consultants in pediatric palliative care met with Minister for Health Simon Harris. The purpose of the meeting was to highlight their concerns over the slow progress of a number of key recommendations in the 'Evaluation of the Children's Palliative Care Programme' report launched by the Minister in November 2016.
Intended Results: The priorities for progress included re-establishing a National Development Committee, the extension of the Clinical Nurse Coordinators Service for children with life-limiting illnesses, the development of clinical palliative care services in our children's hospitals and the need for an agreed roadmap for further development of priorities in children's palliative care. The coalition requested immediately progressing the next steps of the Children's Palliative Care Programme.
Lobbying Activities: The meeting was held on Thursday 15 February. CEO of the Irish Hospice Foundation, Sharon Foley was joined by CEO of the Jack and Jill Foundation, Hugo Jellett Dr. Mary Devins, Consultant Paediatrician with a Special Interest in Paediatric Palliative Medicine, Dr. Maeve O’Reilly, Palliative Care Consultant, St. James Hospital and St. Luke’s Hospital and Claire Quinn, Lecturer and Programme Director MHSc /PGD Health Sciences (Children’s Palliative/ Complex Care) at the School of Nursing and Midwifery, NUI Galway.|Meeting|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Hugo Jellett, CEO The Jack & Jill Children's Foundation as part of a coalition of children's palliative care service providers and consultants

Specific Details: More than 60% of all alcohol is now sold via mixed trade retail units. A decade ago 70% of all alcohol was sold & consumed in pubs/restaurants/hotels with the remainder sold in independent off-licences & to a lesser extent supermarkets & mixed trade outlets. This change has contributed to the debate about the effects of binge drinking & a lack of control in this area & has been facilitated to a large extent by the change in S8 (4), Intoxicating Liquor Act 2000 which repealed S13 of the 1960 Act.
DPOs Lobbied: Charles Flanagan|Minister|Department of Justice and Equality::Simon Harris|Minister|Department of Health
Subject Matter: More than 60% of all alcohol is now sold via mixed trade retail units. A decade ago 70% of all alcohol was sold & consumed in pubs/restaurants/hotels with the remainder sold in independent off-licences & to a lesser extent supermarkets & mixed trade outlets. This change has contributed to the debate about the effects of binge drinking & a lack of control in this area & has been facilitated to a large extent by the change in S8 (4), Intoxicating Liquor Act 2000 which repealed S13 of the 1960 Act.
Intended Results: Under the 1960 Act any outlets wishing to set up a premises to sell spirits/beer/wine needed to extinguish 2 licenses so that 1 new licence could be established. The VFI believes the current legislation, which requires only 1 licence, should be reversed so that it would again be necessary to extinguish 2 licences before a new premises could be established, thereby helping address some of the issues around alcohol misuse.

Specific Details: Pre-budget submission: A coalition of children’s palliative care service providers including the Jack & Jill Children's Foundation and consultants in specialist paediatric palliative care called on the Government to prioritise the next steps in Children’s Palliative Care programme in Budget 2019. They encourage the development of multi-annual budgeting to prevent a stop-start approach to these vital services.
DPOs Lobbied: Simon Harris|Minister|Department of Health
Subject Matter: Pre-budget submission: A coalition of children’s palliative care service providers including the Jack & Jill Children's Foundation and consultants in specialist paediatric palliative care called on the Government to prioritise the next steps in Children’s Palliative Care programme in Budget 2019. They encourage the development of multi-annual budgeting to prevent a stop-start approach to these vital services.
Intended Results: Call on the Government to start planning in 2019 for a more strategic approach to future budgets to address children's palliative care needs, in order to achieve a full and comprehensive service provision and support network throughout the country.  Commitment to multi-annual budget provision would be a practical way to ensure the smooth roll out of services.
Lobbying Activities: Wednesday 11th July -  A coalition of children’s palliative care service providers and consultants in specialist presented their Pre-Budget submission to Minister of Health, Simon Harris TD. The group made up of Sharon Foley, CEO Irish Hospice Foundation (IHF), Dr. Mary Devins, Consultant Paediatrician with a Special Interest in Paediatric Palliative Medicine, Dr. Maeve O’Reilly & Dr. Marie Twomey, Consultants in Palliative Medicine, Our Lady’s Children’s Hospital Crumlin and St. Luke’s Hospital, Claire Quinn, Lecturer and Programme Director MHSc /PGD Health Sciences (Children’s Palliative/ Complex Care) at the School of Nursing and Midwifery, NUI Galway, Orla O’Brien, CEO, LauraLynn, Ireland’s Children’s Hospice and interim CEO of the Jack and Jill Foundation, Carmel Doyle.|Submission|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Carmel Doyle - Interim CEO - the Jack & Jill Children's Foundation

Lobbying Activities:
Emails to the Minister's Office regarding International Clinical Trials Day 2018 on 18th May in Farmleigh House in which Minister Harris has provisionally agreed to be our guest of honor.  Minister Harris was unavailable and Muiris O'Connor attended in his place.

International Clinical Trials Day is an annual event when we recognise the work and the fantastic contribution patients, who are participating in cancer trials across the country, are making to cancer research. We also used the day to launch our 2018 Just Ask Your Doctor! public information campaign which was a great opportunity to raise the profile of cancer trials locally and nationally.|Email|2-5::Email sent to Sinead Donohue at the Department of Health informing her of Press Release sent out from us on the 5th July 2018 
  
'Cancer Trials Ireland supports call for trial to open in Ireland to study the effectiveness of the drug Pembrolizumab to treat cervical cancer. '|Letter|1::Letter to Minister Harris looking for his support for a proposed national recognition event.  

Meeting other trials participants can be of itself be an enormously enriching experience and bring great comfort.  It enables people feel part of a national and global effort to protect future generation from the perils of cancer.  Receiving a personalised certificate from Minister would enable this impact to continue and for those who have passed away it would be a poignant legacy to their families.|Letter|1

Specific Details: Letters and follow up meeting between the NSC and the Minister for Health to discuss key challenges in safeguarding adults at risk of abuse in Ireland. Communicate the Strategic Plan and progress to date with the Minister. Advocating for the requirement for interdepartmental working between Health, Justice and The Department of Employment Affairs and Social Protection in bring about positive outcomes for the most vulnerable members of Irish Society.
DPOs Lobbied: Simon Harris|Minister|Department of Health
Subject Matter: Letters and follow up meeting between the NSC and the Minister for Health to discuss key challenges in safeguarding adults at risk of abuse in Ireland. Communicate the Strategic Plan and progress to date with the Minister. Advocating for the requirement for interdepartmental working between Health, Justice and The Department of Employment Affairs and Social Protection in bring about positive outcomes for the most vulnerable members of Irish Society.
Intended Results: Secure increased resourcing for the National Safeguarding Committee to enable the  strategic goals to be achieved.::Enhanced cross departmental engagement to secure better outcomes for adults who are vulnerable and at risk of abuse::Progress Adult Safeguarding Legislation- establishing a whole government approach::Pending the Safeguarding Legislation- progress legislative changes that will provide equal protection for those residing in private nursing homes that have safeguarding concerns.
Lobbying Activities:
Letter outlined the strategic focus of the National Safeguarding Committee most notably in influencing government policy on the development on safeguarding legislation.
Key shortcomings in current legislation were outlined.
Currently responsibility for the development of policy and legislation lies with the Department of Health and the NSC would advocate for a whole government approach in line with international best practice.|Letter|1::Nursing Homes Issue
1. Private Nursing Homes  were excluded from the HSE’s 2014 Safeguarding Vulnerable Persons at Risk of Abuse: National Policy and Procedures but which the NSC believes should be addressed before the finalisation of the current review process.
The NSC therefore suggests that pending the enactment of the detailed Adult Safeguarding Act that the opportunity be taken in forthcoming legislation being finalised this autumn in the form of the Disability (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 2017 and the Assisted Decision-Making (Capacity) (Amendment) Bill to provide for the underpinning of such policies by an appropriate legislative provision.|Letter|1::A number of members of the National Safeguarding Committee met with the Minister for Health to discuss 
1 Strategic plan for the committee
2. Key developments including legislation/standards/ policy
3. Advocating for the need for cross departmental approach, in line with international best practice 
4. Necessary resources required to progress the work of the committee|Meeting|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Patricia Rickard-Clarke, Chair National Safeguarding Committee

Specific Details: Human Tissue Bill and Opt Out Organ Donation System
DPOs Lobbied: simon harris|Minister of State|Department of Health
Subject Matter: Human Tissue Bill and Opt Out Organ Donation System
Intended Results: Inform the Minister for Health and Department of Health of Senator Feargal Quinn's passing and work around the Human Tissue Bill and Organ Donation/Opt Out System
Lobbying Activities:
Irish Lung Fibrosis Association (ILFA) wrote to Minister Simon Harris to inform him that Feargal Quinn, a patron for many years of ILFA, had sadly passed away. 
In 2008, Senator Feargal Quinn wrote a Bill entitled the 'Human Body Organs and Human Tissue Bill'. He was a strong advocate for the opt-out organ donation system and passionately believed in organ donation and transplantation. 

ILFA hopes that Fergal's instrumental role can be acknowledged as we move towards the introduction of the Human Tissue Bill. This will be a great and fitting legacy for Fergal’s wonderful advocacy work.|Email|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Nicola Cassidy, Director of the Irish Lung Fibrosis Association

Specific Details: Letter to Minister for Health Mr Simon Harris regarding general motions passed at the IMO AGM 2019
DPOs Lobbied: Simon Harris|Minister|Department of Health
Subject Matter: Letter to Minister for Health Mr Simon Harris regarding general motions passed at the IMO AGM 2019
Intended Results: The IMO calls on the Government to 1) incentivise sustainable and to penalise unsustainable energy provision and to mandate Government Departments and Agencies to prioritise the procurement of sustainable energy services; 2) to increase investment in cycling and walking to 20% of the transport budget, 3) to prioritise access to healthy, sustainable and culturally appropriate food at all Government funded facilities.::to provide sufficient resources for the extension of the HPV Vaccination Programme in the 2019/20 School Year in order to achieve optimal uptake of this cancer preventing vaccine.::to redouble efforts in promoting the value of screening programmes in terms of saving lives while clearly explaining the inherent limitations of such programmes::to ensure that all “social media” companies and affiliates based in the Republic of Ireland are treated no less onorously than publishing companies in regards to regulations on the protection of children in the new proposed online safety act and to establish statutory guidelines for 'social media' companies and affiliates based in the Republic of Ireland in regards to Suicide Prevention and identification of vulnerable adults.::to ensure that when introducing any new regulation into the health sector that adequate engagement with the medical profession has taken place and it is accompanied by an impact statement on the benefits and negative effects, including resource implications to the healthcare system.::to review investment in sports facilities and sporting organisations at non elite level, non-competitive level, community and school level to improve participation levels in exercise and in the overall health of society.::to review the rules and methodology around the gathering of data for the HIPE system so as to ensure that the data accurately reflects all patients including those admitted on trolleys in Emergency Departments and to ensure that OECD data on healthcare accurately reflects the expenditure and levels of activity across the health system both public and private.::to ensure there is a national electronic patient record put in place in all health services in Ireland.::to recognise that fatigue amongst doctors and other healthcare staff is a danger to both the staff member and patients and to immediately work with the IMO and Postgraduate Training Bodies to develop, resource and support policies to create a safer and healthier environment.::1)to resource and enact a 6 Hour Target for Emergency Departments 2) to invest in an accelerated programme of Acute Hospital Capacity not at the minimum requirement of 2,600 additional beds but at a more realistic 5,000 bed requirement level to meet patient demand; 3) to examine and publish details of the expected flow of patients and additional resources required to be put in place to appropriately manage the patients in advance of any reconfiguration of services::to urgently review commitments with respect to development of retrieval services in order to ensure capacity and capability to provide a robust and consistent national critical care retrieval service, particularly for areas which are outside of the recommended travel times to Trauma Centres/Units and to urgently review the constraints which need to be overcome for 24/7 access to onsite HEMS service to avoid road transfers to pre-identified landing sites.::to organise a resourced campaign highlighting the dangers of Cannabis use.::to ensure that there is more regulation on health food stores/purveyors of vitamin and supplement products especially in light that the FSAI have indicated concern with the exponential use of these products in the absence of evidence of need and that they only advise the need for Folate and Vitamin D in specific circumstances.
Lobbying Activities: Letter to Minister for Health Mr Simon Harris TD|Letter|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Vanessa Hetherington, Assistant Director, Policy and International affairs

Specific Details: General Scheme of Patient Safety Bill 2018
DPOs Lobbied: Simon Harris|Minister|Department of Health
Subject Matter: General Scheme of Patient Safety Bill 2018
Intended Results: 1) to ensure the definition of patient safety incident excludes adverse events that are not the result of a patient safety incidents 2) to ensure mandatory reporting of patient safety events applies to providers and not individual practitioners who are already subject to sanctions by their statutory regulator::to review  current procedures and prescribed statements for open disclosure under Part 4 of the Civil Liability (Amendment) Act 2017 to ensure that they are fit for purpose and do not negatively impact on the doctor-patient relationship and to ensure non-medical factors such as resource issues, understaffing, systems failures are included in the disclosure process.::to review the law in relation to gross negligence manslaughter::to ensure the notification of patient safety incidents and records created for the purpose of  clinical audit are afforded the same protections as under the Part 4 of the Civil Liability (Amendment) Act 2017::to ensure HIQA’s remit should be extended to cover all private healthcare facilities::to ensure appropriate resources and supports are provided to implement the HSE’s open disclosure policy across the health services - not only in hospital services but across the health system including General Practice and community health services.::to ensure that management in hospitals and other designated services are subject to accountability in the same manner as the medical profession.::to give consideration to establishing a Medical Injuries Assessment Board (similar to the PIAB) to assess certain clinical negligence cases.
Lobbying Activities: Submission to the Minister for Health, Mr Simon Harris TD|Submission|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Vanessa Hetherington, Assistant Director, Policy and International Affairs

Specific Details: Dept of Health Consultation on Climate Change Adaption Plan for the Health Sector
DPOs Lobbied: Simon Harris|Minister|Department of Health
Subject Matter: Dept of Health Consultation on Climate Change Adaption Plan for the Health Sector
Intended Results: Fully implement the recommendations contained in the Crowe Horwath Report to be including the immediate awarding of consultant status and remuneration to public health specialists in line with their specialist training and experience, allowing them to work to the top of their licence. The  Crowe Horwath implementation process needs to ensure that Consultants in Public Health Medicine are empowered and facilitated to provide effective leadership in climate change adaptation.::Coordinated planning across government and within the health sector to minimise climate health impacts and to maximise the quality of care to those that need health services.::Prioritise the recruitment and retention of essential medical staff in anticipation of increasing healthcare demand.  This means  immediately addressing the two-tier pay system that is contributing to the current crisis in consultant recruitment and retention and further investment in the development of General Practice.

Subject Matter: I am involved the the COVID-19 working group fro the ELE sector. I have been in touch with individuals regarding challenges facing the ELE sector at this challenging time. I have made proposals regarding IRP cards (move on-line), Refunds and potentially vulnerable students. I also lobbied for the Irish government to work closely with the Northern Ireland Executive in relation to an island wide action plan to dealing with COVID-19.

I also made proposals of how schools could be supported after COVID-19 passes. Such as allowing evening classes as well as morning and afternoon classes. I also want schools to be made to offer something on-line during COVID-19 closures, at present some schools are doing nothing for their students and I feel this unacceptable.

Specific Details: For parents who have children with complex medical needs, the HSE policy of 'In Loco Parentis' compels parents to provide a 'competent adult' to be in the home. This policy applies even when a qualified nurse is there should the parents decide to leave the home. Jack & Jill are advocating, as part of Jack & Jill’s manifesto for General Election 2020, that the implementation of the policy of 'In Loco Parentis' must be reversed and are urging the Government, to abolish this clause.

Specific Details: Concern for people with an intellectual disability living in residential & community settings. 7,530 are in receipt of full-time residential care. 4,389 live in community group homes/ 2,005 live in residential centres. Many have complex medical & psychiatric conditions.They are at a greater risk of Covid-19 due to their higher prevalence of comorbid health problems & reduced abilities. They have a right to protection & access to hospital & other healthcare interventions like every Irish citizen.
DPOs Lobbied: Simon Harris|Minister|Department of Health::Tony Holohan|Chief Medical Officer|Department of Health::Jim Daly|Minister of State|Department of Health
Subject Matter: Concern for people with an intellectual disability living in residential & community settings. 7,530 are in receipt of full-time residential care. 4,389 live in community group homes/ 2,005 live in residential centres. Many have complex medical & psychiatric conditions.They are at a greater risk of Covid-19 due to their higher prevalence of comorbid health problems & reduced abilities. They have a right to protection & access to hospital & other healthcare interventions like every Irish citizen.
Intended Results: Minister Harris, Department of Public Health & HSE to give immediate, urgent & focussed attention to protect the lives of this most vulnerable group.Their right to assessment & treatment in hospital for Covid-19 and /or other medical conditions during this pandemic, whether living in residential or community settings, should be no different to any other Irish citizen. They require access to rapid testing & results, adequate PPE, infection control expertise and extra staffing.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Dr William Flannery, President and Dr Patricia Walsh, Chair, Faculty of Learning Disability Psychiatry

Specific Details: Concern for children with an intellectual disability living in residential and community settings. At this critical time, these children and their parents and carers are at increased risk of fatigue and burnout without essential supports. They have a right to protection and access to hospital & other healthcare interventions like every other Irish citizen. Health and social care staff providing essential services to these children during the Covid-19 pandemic are needed.
DPOs Lobbied: Simon Harris|Minister|Department of Health::Jim Daly|Minister of State|Department of Health::Tony Holohan|Chief Medical Officer|Department of Health
Subject Matter: Concern for children with an intellectual disability living in residential and community settings. At this critical time, these children and their parents and carers are at increased risk of fatigue and burnout without essential supports. They have a right to protection and access to hospital & other healthcare interventions like every other Irish citizen. Health and social care staff providing essential services to these children during the Covid-19 pandemic are needed.
Intended Results: Immediate urgent and focused attention to protecting the lives of children with an intellectual disability and their parents/carers They require strong HSE/Public health support and guidance to support them through the pandemic. Prioritised for rapid testing and results when required. Staff in hospital/disability settings to be provided with adequate PPE, dedicated low stimulus settings to assess and treat these children, infection control expertise and additional staffing.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Dr William Flannery, President and Dr Louise Sharkey, Consultant Child & Adolescent & Intellectual Disability Psychiatrist

Specific Details: Supports for Irish emigrants returning in need during the Covid-19 crisis
DPOs Lobbied: Simon Harris|Minister|Department of Health
Subject Matter: Supports for Irish emigrants returning in need during the Covid-19 crisis
Intended Results: In the immediate term, we are proposing: 1)	Designating the Healthlink team as the official contact point for anyone returning home into homelessness – with a referral protocol for Consular and other services likes ours  2) Designating the HSE City West facility (or another suitable facility) as an official location for in-need returnees to self-isolate, if they have no alternative, for the mandated 14 days.
Lobbying Activities:
I am writing regarding Irish emigrants who are returning to Ireland due to Covid-19, and who are in difficult and sometimes vulnerable circumstances.  We are funded through the Department of Foreign Affairs’ Emigrant Support Programme and have a long history of supporting Irish citizens returning home in crisis.  This work has taken on a new level of challenge and complexity since the start of the pandemic.  
Your colleague Ciaran Cannon TD, Minister for the Diaspora, forwarded a letter to you on my request (dated 8 May 2020).  I would like to add further details and updates.  
I am writing regarding two distinct groups of returnees: (1) those returning into homelessness, and (2) those without finances who need access to self-isolation facilities as they are returning to family homes where there are at-risk or vulnerable family members.|Letter|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Mr Richard King, Project Leader, Crosscare Migrant Project

Lobbyist Name: Responsible Retailing of Alcohol Ireland Limited (RRAI)
Specific Details: Public Health (Alcohol) Act 2018 Section 22
DPOs Lobbied: Simon Harris|Minister|Department of Health
Subject Matter: Public Health (Alcohol) Act 2018 Section 22
Intended Results: The RRAI seeking to understand the administrative approach to be followed by the Environmental Health Service when determining compliance with the standards set out in Section 22 of the Public Health (Alcohol) Act 2018 as retailers transition to these new requirements.
Lobbying Activities:
Letters sent by the RRAI to Minister for Health Simon Harris TD on 01 May, 27 May and 03 June. The letters reiterated the commitment of RRAI members to implement the requirements set out in Section 22 of the PHAA in a verifiable and credible manner cognisant of the practical challenges posed by the COVID 19 emergency.
The letters sought to understand in practical terms what adminsitraive approach would be followed by the EHS when determining compliance with the standards set out in Section 22 of the PHAA 2018 as retailers transition to these new requirements.
Of principal concern was how access and eggress solutions into and out of the separated alcohol selling area, could be practically implemented by retailers while complying with the requirements set out in Option A of Section 22. The legslation is silent on this matter.|Letter|2-5

Specific Details: Introduction to An Cosán - early years education & care, family supports, adult education (Foundation, Further, Higher), counselling & other wrap around supports for learners.  We presented the challenges faced by many learners as a result of the digital divide. An Cosán has the knowledge and skills and reach across Ireland to address this problem. This issue is increasingly important in this digitised world and most particularly during the pandemic.
DPOs Lobbied: Sarah Bardon|Special Adviser|Department of Further and Higher Education, Innovation and Science::Simon Harris|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Introduction to An Cosán - early years education & care, family supports, adult education (Foundation, Further, Higher), counselling & other wrap around supports for learners.  We presented the challenges faced by many learners as a result of the digital divide. An Cosán has the knowledge and skills and reach across Ireland to address this problem. This issue is increasingly important in this digitised world and most particularly during the pandemic.
Intended Results: The aim of our communication is to increase awareness & to advocate on behalf of those most marginalised and disadvantaged within our society. Our aim to advocate for the 52% of Irish people who don’t possess at least basic digital skills & who don't have access to technology. The need we wish to address: To equip educators, community workers and parents with the digital capacity to participate in a digitised society.

Specific Details: NISIG is the only Irish charity supporting and advocacy on behalf of those experiencing fertility issues. NISIG is now part of a broader AHR Coalition Group formed in 2020 comprising LGBT Ireland, 221 Plus group, Equality for Children and the Rainbow Families Equality Network.  A main aim of the coalition is to ensure that equality is secured, and the human rights of children conceived using AHR, their intended parents and families are protected and advanced in legislation and policy.

Specific Details: Advocating for supplementary payment for social care students, due to COVID 19 restrictions could not complete placements, some students will have too complete placements hours during the summer months.
DPOs Lobbied: Simon Harris|Minister|Department of Further and Higher Education, Innovation and Science::Heather Humphreys|Minister|Department of Social Protection
Subject Matter: Advocating for supplementary payment for social care students, due to COVID 19 restrictions could not complete placements, some students will have too complete placements hours during the summer months.
Intended Results: Raise awareness around the challenges for students that have to take the summer off to complete practice placements
Lobbying Activities:
1.	Many students will have to complete their placement hours over the summer months, thereby extending their academic year. We would advocate for this being supported in some way, specifically for students who are accessing SUSI grants and who may now be disadvantaged as a result of this particular situation. In addition, many students rely on the summertime employment to fund their studies. 
2.	We have had communication with a number of social care agencies who have committed to supporting our students to return to placement. However, some are requesting that students do not engage in other work during their completion of placement, due to concerns regarding cross-contamination. These concerns are entirely valid, and we appreciate and value the commitment that agencies demonstrate towards our students, however this is additionally disadvantaging our students who rely on part-time work to fund their studies.
3.	Students with children may face additional childcare costs during the summe|Letter|2-5
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Helena Doody director on the board of Social Care Ireland and member of the Education Advisory Group within SCI

Lobbyist Name: Breaking Through Company Limited by Guarantee
Specific Details: Submission to Minister Harris in relation to the review of the SUSI grant system on behalf of members of the Irish Aftercare Network. ( sent 15th March 2021)
DPOs Lobbied: Simon Harris|Minister|Department of Further and Higher Education, Innovation and Science
Subject Matter: Submission to Minister Harris in relation to the review of the SUSI grant system on behalf of members of the Irish Aftercare Network. ( sent 15th March 2021)
Intended Results: On behalf of young people in aftercare and Aftercare Workers facing this difficulty, we propose that an extra point be added to the eligibility criteria for young people with such immigration status, which would entitle them to support if they have spent (x) years in the care of the State::We propose that there be more discretion and an option to appeal SUSI decisions on mental health grounds in order to secure funding for a repeat year in the case of a young person who has a history of being in the care of the State. Given these students’ care histories, likely potential experiences of trauma, and the many obstacles they will likely have overcome by the time they reach third level education we suggest flexibility and discretion in relation to support::we propose that a designated officer within SUSI be appointed so that Aftercare Workers (and young people) can correspond directly with someone about the specific issues they are facing. In some other areas, for example housing, Aftercare Workers have a person they can contact directly within County Councils when issues arise around a young person’s accommodation. We believe something similar could work very well if SUSI were to offer this to Aftercare workers
Lobbying Activities: Submission to Minister Harris in relation to the review of the SUSI grant system on behalf of members of the Irish Aftercare Network. ( sent 15th March 2021)|Submission|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Dr Eavan Brady ( on behalf of Irish Aftercare Network)

Specific Details: Strengthened Mandate for Skillnet Ireland
DPOs Lobbied: Simon Harris|Minister|Department of Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science::Deirdre Duffy|Special Adviser|Department of Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science
Subject Matter: Strengthened Mandate for Skillnet Ireland
Intended Results: The meeting followed engagement between the Department and Skillnet Ireland on the policy area of workforce development and its important in the context of ongoing competitiveness of the enterprise sector. Further discussion with officials and with the Minister on the mandate of Skillnet Ireland with respect to workforce development for the enterprise sector, further discussion on the potential to strengthen or renew the mandate in that context, and clarity on next steps.
Lobbying Activities:
Location: Dept of Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science, St. Stephens Green, Dublin

Agenda: 
•Workforce development as a critical competitiveness issue/ opportunity for Ireland. (Workforce Development meaning: Development of middle and high skills in the labour market, skills in the context of industry 4.0, talent supply for the FDI sector and boosting SME innovation/ competitiveness) 
•The benefits of a designated agency spearheading workforce development, coordinating a joined-up system wide approach.
•The future role of Skillnet Ireland with respect to workforce development as the Government agency with extensive partnerships with industry and employees.
•The current and future role of Skillnet Ireland in helping prime tertiary provision for the future needs of the economy.

Other Attendees:  Mary McGarry PO DFHERIS ;  Stephanie O’Brien PO DFHERIS ;Brendan McGinty, Chair Skillnet Ireland|Meeting|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Paul Healy, Chief Executive, Skillnet Ireland

Specific Details: QQI charges for HECA member higher education institutions (HEIs).
DPOs Lobbied: Simon Harris|Minister|Department of Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science::Keith Moynes|Assistant Secretary|Department of Further and Higher Education, Innovation and Science::Colm O'Reardon|Secretary General|Department of Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science
Subject Matter: QQI charges for HECA member higher education institutions (HEIs).
Intended Results: HECA requests urgent intervention for addressing escalating QQI costs impacting private/independent HEIs. Emphasising the need for a fair and sustainable fee system, we highlight the disproportionate financial strain these charges impose on our sector, compared to public institutions. We seek a balanced approach that recognises the unique challenges and operational models of our HEIs, ensuring their competitiveness and viability in the national and global education landscapes.

Specific Details: EU Regulatory Data Protection Policy and Reimbursement Policy
DPOs Lobbied: Simon Harris|An Taoiseach|Department of the Taoiseach::Clare Mungovan|Special Adviser|Department of the Taoiseach::Sarah Bardon|Special Adviser|Department of Further and Higher Education, Innovation and Science
Subject Matter: EU Regulatory Data Protection Policy and Reimbursement Policy
Intended Results: That Government continues to recognise the strategic importance of the pharmaceutical industry and continues to be a strong policy advocate not simply to finesse or avoid a cut in Regulatory Data Protection, but to strengthen inter-related IP supports for medicines in Europe as the legislation now moves to the European Council for deliberation, ::That Government understands that the reimbursement of new medicines policy needs to be solidified on a multi-annual basis to prevent further delays to patients in Ireland accessing treatment.::that the findings of the Mazars report are fully implemented to improve transparency in the reimbursement process and that the staffing levels for reimbursement of medicines is increased to reduces current delays. Ireland is lagging its counterparts, ranking 22nd out of 27 EU Member States in terms of speed at which medicines are reimbursed and policy direction is needed to improve this.

Specific Details: Concerns about unifying the National Learner Protection Fund under the QQI Amendment Act 2019, merging the ELE sector with HEIs.
DPOs Lobbied: Simon Harris|Minister|Department of Further and Higher Education, Innovation and Science::Keith Moynes|Assistant Secretary|Department of Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science::Colm O'Reardon|Secretary General|Department of Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science
Subject Matter: Concerns about unifying the National Learner Protection Fund under the QQI Amendment Act 2019, merging the ELE sector with HEIs.
Intended Results:
Highlight the significant differences between ELE and HEIs in operations, demographics, and regulations. ELE's short-term courses differ in risk profile from HEIs' validated programmes. Unified fund may unfairly burden HEIs with ELE's higher risks. ::Consider retaining the successful elements of existing schemes; HECA PEL Scheme has protected learners without state cost. 
::Clarification on the concerns about new fund's accumulation and financial threshold and the
potential permanent annual burden on students.

Subject Matter: USI's lobbying work with the Minister for Further and Higher Education for the relevant period
Intended Results: Student Accommodation: The publication of the National Student Accommodation Strategy  - The enforcement of planning permissions against the owners of private student accommodation with regards to compulsory length leases - an update on the standardized design for student accommodation - the development of a framework for allowing Technological Universities to borrow state funding for the development of student accommodation - the enactment of the Residential Tenancies (Amendment) Bill 2023.  ::Mental Health and Student Supports - ensuring that the funding dedicated to the Student Assistance Fund is matched annually permanently - a policy for informing students of any hidden costs from the outset - accommodation services for students that are sent away from home on mandatory placement programs. ::Postgraduate Supports: Workers' Status for postgraduate researchers - issues regarding visas of the spouses of postgraduate researchers - full state funding to bring the stipend amount for all postgraduate researchers in line with the findings of the Independent Review into State Supports for Postgraduate Researchers which is €25k per annum. ::Students fleeing conflict zones: the production of a national policy for the enrollment and support of students that have fled conflict zones in Irish higher education institutions with a focus on those evacuated by the Dept of Foreign Affairs from Gaza. ::Gaeilge - a comprehensive education policy for the teaching of the Irish Language from pre-school through to Third-level Education.
Lobbying Activities: Meeting with Minister Simon Harris at Leinster House to discuss the intended results. Attended by various USI officers and officials from the department's Student Support Unit, Student Accommodation Unit, and Innovation, Research and Development Policy.|Meeting|1::Followed up with the Minister's staff and Departmental staff regarding the enrollment of students evacuated by the DFA from Gaza. |Email|2-5::Various conversations with Departmental Staff at the Annual Funding the Futures event relating to follow up on the intended results outlined above. |Informal communication|2-5

Specific Details: 1) Seeking to progress current situation regarding Irish people released on licence in UK; 2) Seeking to progress the repatriation of Irish prisoners overseas wishing to return to Ireland; 3) Discussing recent research on Foreign National Prisoners in Irish prisons by Maynooth University in partnership with ICPO and findings from research which, if implemented, would improve the situation of foreign national prisoners in Irish prisons.
DPOs Lobbied: Simon Harris|An Taoiseach|Department of the Taoiseach::Thomas Pringle|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Caron McCaffrey|Director General|Irish Prison Service::Ben Ryan|Assistant Secretary|Department of Justice
Subject Matter: 1) Seeking to progress current situation regarding Irish people released on licence in UK; 2) Seeking to progress the repatriation of Irish prisoners overseas wishing to return to Ireland; 3) Discussing recent research on Foreign National Prisoners in Irish prisons by Maynooth University in partnership with ICPO and findings from research which, if implemented, would improve the situation of foreign national prisoners in Irish prisons.
Intended Results: 1) Policy change to allow the small number of Irish people wishing to return to Ireland while on licence from the UK to do so; 2) Improvements to current process to make it quicker and more efficient thus enabling transfers of Irish prisoners back to Ireland close to families; 3) Improvements to the situation of Foreign National prisoners in Irish prisons.
Lobbying Activities: One letter sent by Bishop Paul Dempsey, Chair, ICPO to An Taoiseach and one reply letter received from the Taoiseach's office.|Letter|2-5::Two virtual meetings held on Zoom.  Meetings were had with Ms Caron McCaffrey and other officials from the Irish Prison Service and with Mr Ben Ryan from the Department of Justice and other officials attended.|Virtual Meeting|2-5::Two e-mails from Mr Thomas Pringle TD with responses from the Minister for Justice to a PQ he had asked on behalf of ICPO - recorded in last Lobbying period).|Email|2-5
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Bishop Paul Dempsey, Chair, ICPO; Ms Leslie Alcock, Coordinator, ICPO and Ms Catherine Kenny, Casework Information and Policy Officer, ICPO

for the Government to implement effective sustainability and adaptation actions and to improve their Climate Action Plans.
for all Govt Departments to carry out and publish comprehensive and meaningful Health Impact Assessments, as recommended by the WHO when developing policies or major projects so as to improve and protect the health of our citizens. HIAs should be meaningfully considered in the context of air pollution, environmental hazards and the social determinants of health.::Considering the wider determinants of health, which are outside of doctors’ control, are responsible for most illness, those who make decisions that may adversely affect the health and well-being of people should be expected to have similar high standards in terms of ethical training, and accountability as expected from doctors. The IMO calls on Government to reflect these standards in their decision making.

Specific Details: Conflict in Gaza
DPOs Lobbied: Simon Harris|An Taoiseach|Department of the Taoiseach
Subject Matter: Conflict in Gaza
Intended Results: The IMO recognises the dire circumstances of the healthcare system, medical teams and civilian population in Gaza and calls on the Irish Government, the European Commission and the European Parliament to use all diplomatic and financial avenues available to support all relevant agencies on the ground in the provision of healthcare, including the reinstatement and augmentation of funding to UNWRA.::That the IMO supports recognises and supports the position of the United Nations and the International Court of Justice on the war in Gaza and calls for an immediate ceasefire and the release of hostages. The IMO also condemn the ongoing attacks by the Israeli Government on civilians, healthcare settings and on those seeking to provide care and aid to the people of Gaza.  ::We call on the Irish Government, to review their procurement chains and associations so as to ensure they are in line with the UN and ICJ Rulings and Directives and that any procurement does not support military action.
